fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose that \mathcal {C} is a cartesian category with images that commute with pullbacks. Let f\colon A\to B be a morphism and g\colon B'\twoheadrightarrow B be a cover. Then note that \mathsf {Img}(g) is an isomorphism. Since images commute with pullbacks by hypothesis, we can form the following diagram.

Since isomorphisms are stable under pullback, f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)) is also an isomorphism. Thus, \mathsf {Img}(f^{*}(g)) is an isomorphism. Then since f^{*}(g) is the composite of two covers, it is itself a cover.
A category \mathcal {C} is regular iff it is cartesian and has images that commute with pullbacks, i.e., the following diagram commutes up to isomorphism for any object f \in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}, sw = {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}, ne = \mathsf {Sub}(B), se = \mathsf {Sub}(A), north = \mathsf {Img}, south = \mathsf {Img}, west = f^{*}, east = f^{*}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose that \mathcal {C} is a cartesian category with images that commute with pullbacks. Let f\colon A\to B be a morphism and g\colon B'\twoheadrightarrow B be a cover. Then note that \mathsf {Img}(g) is an isomorphism. Since images commute with pullbacks by hypothesis, we can form the following diagram.

Since isomorphisms are stable under pullback, f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)) is also an isomorphism. Thus, \mathsf {Img}(f^{*}(g)) is an isomorphism. Then since f^{*}(g) is the composite of two covers, it is itself a cover.

If \mathcal {C} is regular, then by , the unit \vartheta \colon \mathsf {id}\to \mathsf {Img} consists of covers. Let f\colon A\to B be any morphism in \mathcal {C} and g\colon B'\to B be an object in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}. By , g can be factored as \vartheta _{g}\mathsf {Img}(g). Form the following pullbacks. Note that since covers are stable under pullback by hypothesis, \widehat {\vartheta _{g}} is also a cover. Then by the pasting lemma, the composite f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)) \circ \widehat {\vartheta _{g}} is isomorphic to f^{*}(g) in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}.
Thus, f^{*}(g) admits another cover-mono factorization.
Then by uniqueness, C \cong \underline {A'}. Thus, \mathsf {Img}(f^{*}(g)) \cong f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)).
